JavaScript - Basic Data Structures

Basics

Use an array to store a collection of data

An array data structure is used to store data of various types. The simplest array is a one-dimensional array, with only one level.

A complex array, multidimensional array:

let complexArray = [
    [
        {
            one: 1,
            two: 2
        },
        {
            three: 3,
            four: 4
        },
    ],
    [
        {
            a: "a",
            b: "b"
        },
        {
            c: "c",
            d: "d"
        }
    ]
];

All arrays have a length property: array.length.

Access an array's content using bracket notation

Accessing an array's data can be done by calling using bracket notation, allowing content to be referenced or altered.

let myArray = ["a", "b", "c", "d"];
myArray[1] = "hello";
console.log(myArray);

Modifying Arrays

Add items to an array with push() and unshift()

Array.push() and array.unshift() are used to add items to the beginning and end of the array.

Push adds items to the end of the array.

Unshift adds items to the start of the array.

function mixedNumbers(arr) {
  arr.unshift('I', 2, 'three');
  arr.push(7, 'VIII', 9);
  return arr;
}
console.log(mixedNumbers(['IV', 5, 'six']));
// Returns: [ 'I', 2, 'three', 'IV', 5, 'six', 7, 'VIII', 9 ]

Remove items from an array with pop and shift

Pop removes an element from the end of an array.

Shift removes an element from the start of an array.

let greetings = ['whats up?', 'hello', 'see ya!'];

greetings.pop;
// now equals ['whats up?', 'hello']

greetings.shift;
// now equals ['hello']

The main thing to remember is than neither pop and shift take arguments, and each only allows an array to be modified by a single element at a time.

It is possible to assign the removed values to a new variable:

let popped = greetings.pop;
// returns 'hello'
// greetings now equals []

Remove items using splice()

Splice() allows you to remove any number of consecutive items from the middle of the array.

It can take up to three parameters, these are the first two:

  • from what index should splice() start;
  • and how many items should splice remove.
const arr = [2, 4, 5, 1, 7, 5, 2, 1];
arr.splice(1, 4);
console.log(arr);
// Returns: [ 2, 5, 2, 1 ]

Adding items with the third splice() parameter

Using the third parameter of splice we can add one or more items.

We have defined a function, htmlColorNames, which takes an array of HTML colors as an argument. Modify the function using splice() to remove the first two elements of the array and add 'DarkSalmon' and 'BlanchedAlmond' in their respective places.

function htmlColorNames(arr) {
  arr.splice(0, 2, 'DarkSalmon', 'BlanchedAlmond');
  return arr;
}

console.log(htmlColorNames(['DarkGoldenRod', 'WhiteSmoke', 'LavenderBlush', 'PaleTurquoise', 'FireBrick']));
// returns: 
[ 'DarkSalmon',
  'BlanchedAlmond',
  'LavenderBlush',
  'PaleTurquoise',
  'FireBrick' ]

Moving Arrays

Copy array items using slice()

Rather than modifying an array, slice() copies or extracts a number of elements to a new array.

It leaves the original array untouched.

Slice takes two parameters:

  • the index where to begin;
  • and the index where to end.

*Note - `slice(2, 4) will NOT include the fifth item[4] of the array.

We have defined a function, forecast, that takes an array as an argument. Modify the function using slice() to extract information from the argument array and return a new array that contains the elements 'warm' and 'sunny'. 

function forecast(arr) {
  return arr.slice(2, 4);
}

console.log(forecast(['cold', 'rainy', 'warm', 'sunny', 'cool', 'thunderstorms']));

// Returns: [ 'warm', 'sunny' ]

Copy an array with the spread operator

New in ES6, the spread operator copies all of an array's elements in order.

The spread syntax simply looks like: ...

Example:

let thisArray = [true, true, undefined, false, null];
let thatArray = [...thisArray];
// thatArray equals [true, true, undefined, false, null]
// thisArray remains unchanged and thatArray contains the same elements as thisArray

Exercise:

We have defined a function, copyMachine which takes arr (an array) and num (a number) as arguments. The function is supposed to return a new array made up of num copies of arr. We have done most of the work for you, but it doesn't work quite right yet. Modify the function using spread syntax so that it works correctly (hint: another method we have already covered might come in handy here!).

function copyMachine(arr, num) {
  let newArr = [];
  while (num >= 1) {
    let obj = [...arr];
    newArr.push(obj);
    num--;
  }
  return newArr;
}

console.log(copyMachine([true, false, true], 2));

Combine arrays with the spread operator

Another hige advantage of the spread operator is the ability to combine arrays.

Example:

let thisArray = ['sage', 'rosemary', 'parsley', 'thyme'];

let thatArray = ['basil', 'cilantro', ...thisArray, 'coriander'];
// thatArray now equals ['basil', 'cilantro', 'sage', 'rosemary', 'parsley', 'thyme', 'coriander']

Assessing Arrays

Check for the presence of an element with indexOf()

To figure out the presence and index of an element within an array, indexOf() allows you to check.

The parameter indexOf takes is the element you are looking for.

It will return the index or position if the element is present, and -1 if it isn't present.

Exercise:

indexOf() can be incredibly useful for quickly checking for the presence of an element on an array. We have defined a function, quickCheck, that takes an array and an element as arguments. Modify the function using indexOf() so that it returns true if the passed element exists on the array, and false if it does not.

function quickCheck(arr, elem) {
  if (arr.indexOf(elem) >= 0) {
    return true;
  } else {
    return false;
  }
}

console.log(quickCheck(['squash', 'onions', 'shallots'], 'mushrooms'));

Iterate through all an array's items using for loops

Sometimes when working with arrays you need to iterate through each item to find one or more elements.

JavaScript offers various built in methods, such as: every(), forEach(), map(), to iterate over arrays, but a simple for loop is perfect for the job.

Consider:

function greaterThanTen(arr) {
    let newArr = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {
        if (arr[i] > 10) {
            newArr.push(arr[i]);
        }
    }
    return newArr;
}

greaterThanTen([2, 12, 8, 14, 80, 0, 1]);
// returns [12, 14, 80]

Exercise:

We have defined a function, filteredArray, which takes arr, a nested array, and elem as arguments, and returns a new array. elem represents an element that may or may not be present on one or more of the arrays nested within arr. Modify the function, using a for loop, to return a filtered version of the passed array such that any array nested within arr containing elem has been removed.

function filteredArray(arr, elem) {
  let newArr = [];
  //Iterate each subarray:
  for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {
    //if the subarray does not contain elem:
    if (arr[i].indexOf(elem) != -1) {
      continue;
    // When it does, place in newArr:
    } else {
      newArr.push(arr[i]);
    }
  }
  return newArr;
}

console.log(filteredArray([[3, 2, 3], [1, 6, 3], [3, 13, 26], [19, 3, 9]], 3));

Array Types Expanded & Objects

Create complex multi-dimensional arrays

Arrays can contain, or be made completely out of other arrays. It makes an array into a complex data storing device: a multi-dimensional, or nested array.

An array can have many levels, which can each be reached with the bracket notation.

console.log(nestedArray[2][1][0][0][0]);
// logs: deepest-est?

Add key-value pairs to JavaScript objects

Key-value pairs are collected in objects, each a piece of data (value) mapped to a unique identifier (properties/keys).

Example:

const tekkenCharacter = {
  player: 'Hwoarang',
  fightingStyle: 'Tae Kwon Doe',
  human: true
};

Adding a property is easy, using the dot notation:

tekkenCharacter.origin = 'South Korea';

Or by using the bracket notation:

tekkenCharacter['hair color'] = 'dyed orange';

*Note - Bracket notation is required if the property has a space in it or if you want to use a variable to name the property. Without quotes it will be evaluated as a variable.

const eyes = 'eye color';

tekkenCharacter[eyes] = 'brown';

Modify an object nested within an object

Like arrays, objects in JavaScript can also consist of multiple levels.

Items in these levels can be reached and modified, consider:

let nestedObject = {
  id: 28802695164,
  date: 'December 31, 2016',
  data: {
    totalUsers: 99,
    online: 80,
    onlineStatus: {
      active: 67,
      away: 13,
      busy: 8
    }
  }
};

To assign the value 10 to the busy property, dot notation can be used, like so:

nestedObject.data.onlineStatus.busy = 10;

Access property names with bracket notation

Imagine that the foods object is being used in a program for a supermarket cash register. We have some function that sets the selectedFood and we want to check our foods object for the presence of that food. It might look like:

let selectedFood = getCurrentFood(scannedItem);
let inventory = foods[selectedFood];

This code will evaluate the value stored in the selectedFood variable and return the value of that key in the foods object, or undefined if it's not present.

Bracket notation is very useful because sometimes object properties are not known before runtime or we need to access them in a more dynamic way.

let foods = {
  apples: 25,
  oranges: 32,
  plums: 28,
  bananas: 13,
  grapes: 35,
  strawberries: 27
};

function checkInventory(scannedItem) {
  return foods[scannedItem];
}

console.log(checkInventory("apples"));

Modifying Objects

Use the delete keyword to remove object properties

To remove a key-value pair from an object, we can use the delete keyword, like so:

delete foods.apples;

Example:

let foods = {
  apples: 25,
  oranges: 32,
  plums: 28,
  bananas: 13,
  grapes: 35,
  strawberries: 27
};

delete foods.oranges, delete foods.plums, delete foods.strawberries;

console.log(foods); //returns: { apples: 25, bananas: 13, grapes: 35 }

Check if an object has a property

To check if an object has a certain property, there are two methods:

  • hasOwnProperty(),
  • and in keyword.

Consider an object with property Alan:

users.hasOwnProperty('Alan');
'Alan' in users;
// both return true

Exercise:

// Returns `true` if everyone is present

let users = {
  Alan: {
    age: 27,
    online: true
  },
  Jeff: {
    age: 32,
    online: true
  },
  Sarah: {
    age: 48,
    online: true
  },
  Ryan: {
    age: 19,
    online: true
  }
};

function isEveryoneHere(obj) {
  // Only change code below this line
  if ('Alan' in users && 'Jeff' in users && 'Sarah' in users && 'Ryan' in users) {
    return true;
  } else {
    return false;
  }
  // Only change code above this line
}

console.log(isEveryoneHere(users));

Iterate through the keys of an object with a for...in statement

A for...in statement is a special syntax to iterate through all keys within an object.

For object users, this could look like:

for (let user in users) {
  console.log(user);
}

// logs:
Alan
Jeff
Sarah
Ryan

In this statement, we defined a variable user, and as you can see, this variable was reset during each iteration to each of the object's keys as the statement looped through the object, resulting in each user's name being printed to the console.

Note - Objects do not maintain an ordering to stored keys like arrays do; thus a key's position on an object, or the relative order in which it appears, is irrelevant when referencing or accessing that key.

Generate an array of all object keys with Object.keys()

Using Object.keys(), taking an object as argument, we can generate an array which contains all the keys stored in an object.

This will return an array with strings representing each property in the object.

There will be no specific order to the entries in the array.

Exercise:

Finish writing the getArrayOfUsers function so that it returns an array containing all the properties in the object it receives as an argument.

let users = {
  Alan: {
    age: 27,
    online: false
  },
  Jeff: {
    age: 32,
    online: true
  },
  Sarah: {
    age: 48,
    online: false
  },
  Ryan: {
    age: 19,
    online: true
  }
};

function getArrayOfUsers(obj) {
  return Object.keys(obj);
}

console.log(getArrayOfUsers(users));

Modify an array stored in an object

Exercise:

The user object containst three keys. The data key contains five keys, one of which contains an array of friends. From this, you cna see how flexibe objects are as data structures.

Finish writing function addFriends, so that it takes user object and adds the name of the friend argument to the array stored in user.data.friends and returns that array.

let user = {
  name: 'Kenneth',
  age: 28,
  data: {
    username: 'kennethCodesAllDay',
    joinDate: 'March 26, 2016',
    organization: 'freeCodeCamp',
    friends: [
      'Sam',
      'Kira',
      'Tomo'
    ],
    location: {
      city: 'San Francisco',
      state: 'CA',
      country: 'USA'
    }
  }
};

function addFriend(userObj, friend) {
    //Accessing friends and adding to the array:
  userObj.data.friends.push(friend);
  // Returning the modified array into the global scope:
  return userObj.data.friends;
}

console.log(addFriend(user, 'Pete'));
